title: 107_s2746
content: The Act titled "First Responders Support Act of 2002" includes provisions for Homeland Security Liaison Officers. The "First Responders Support Act of 2002" includes provisions for a Chief Homeland Security Liaison Officer appointed by the Secretary of Homeland Security to coordinate activities of liaison officers in each state. The Chief Officer prepares an annual report detailing state and local priorities for first responder organizations and identifies homeland security functions where the Federal role is needed. The "First Responders Support Act of 2002" mandates the Secretary of Homeland Security to designate at least one employee in each state as a Homeland Security Liaison Officer. These officers are responsible for coordinating activities between the Federal Government and State and local entities, making recommendations to Congress on program creation or elimination, and enhancing coordination of Department of Homeland Security priorities within and between states. The "First Responders Support Act of 2002" requires the Department of Homeland Security to appoint a Liaison Officer in each state to coordinate with local first responders, including law enforcement, fire and rescue, medical, emergency, and relief agencies. The Liaison Officer's duties include ensuring coordination between the Department of Homeland Security and state and local law enforcement. The "First Responders Support Act of 2002" mandates the Department of Homeland Security to appoint Liaison Officers in each state to coordinate with local first responders, including law enforcement, fire and rescue, medical, and emergency relief agencies. The officers are responsible for identifying areas needing additional resources, providing training and education on homeland security, eliminating duplicative federal roles, and assisting in priority setting based on first responders' needs. The Liaison Officers appointed by the Department of Homeland Security in each state coordinate with local first responder organizations to identify needs, assist in setting homeland security objectives, and represent state and local priorities to DHS. SEC. 3. FEDERAL INTERAGENCY COMMITTEE ON FIRST RESPONDERS. The Interagency Committee on First Responders coordinates federal agencies involved in law enforcement, fire and rescue, and emergency relief services. It identifies needs, recommends grant programs, streamlines support processes, and sets priorities based on discovered needs. The Interagency Committee on First Responders assists in priority setting based on discovered needs and is composed of various representatives from different government departments. The Interagency Committee on First Responders, under the Department of Homeland Security, includes representatives from various federal agencies such as Immigration and Naturalization Service, Transportation Security Agency, and Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Department of Homeland Security provides administrative support for the committee, including scheduling meetings, preparing agendas, maintaining records, and producing reports. The Interagency Committee on First Responders, chaired annually by its members, meets at the discretion of the Chief Homeland Security Liaison Officer or at least once every 3 months. Responsibilities include maintaining records, producing reports, and reimbursing Advisory Council members. The Advisory Council for the Federal Interagency Committee on First Responders is established. The Advisory Council for the Federal Interagency Committee on First Responders is composed of up to 13 members representing law enforcement, fire and rescue, medical services, and urban and rural communities. The Council selects a chairperson annually. Members receive compensation. The Advisory Council members serve without compensation but can be reimbursed for necessary expenses. They must meet with the Interagency Committee on First Responders at least once every 3 months. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out the provisions of this Act is granted.
